item.title: Social care tax rise: PM defends plan ahead of vote
item.description: Labour's Sir Keir Starmer asks for a guarantee that no one who needs care will have to sell their home.

item.title: Government to shorten HGV driver testing process
item.description: "Rattled" government to fast-track lorry drivers to alleviate chronic shortage, BBC understands.

item.title: Amazon pays £492m in UK tax as sales surge to £20.6bn
item.description: The online retail giant saw UK sales rise by 50% last year amid a Covid-driven hike in demand.

item.title: Green and amber lists could go in travel rules shake-up
item.description: The BBC has been told that the green and amber categories could be removed and replaced with a new system.

item.title: Social care: Will people have to sell their homes?
item.description: In 2019, the Conservatives pledged no-one should have to sell their home to pay for their care.

item.title: Minister admits mistake over Marcus Rashford-Maro Itoje mix-up
item.description: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson confuses the England footballer and rugby player in an interview.

item.title: Paris attacks 2015: Historic trial of 20 suspects opens in France
item.description: Twenty men are on trial in Paris accused of involvement in France's worst post-WWII atrocity.

item.title: Mexico: Powerful earthquake hits Acapulco
item.description: The magnitude-seven quake struck near Acapulco, and was felt around 370 km away in Mexico City.

item.title: Afghanistan: Don't recognise Taliban regime, resistance urges
item.description: The all-men interim cabinet includes names of people on the US and UN most-wanted lists.

item.title: Married At First Sight UK's Nikita Jasmine removed for 'aggression'
item.description: Nikita Jasmine behaved in an "unacceptable" way on the matchmaking show, Channel 4 says.

item.title: Thunderstorms cause flash-flooding in Devon
item.description: Businesses are affected and roads made impassable due to flood water caused by downpours.

item.title: Geronimo the alpaca: TB test results disputed
item.description: The government said it found evidence the animal had the disease, but supporters dispute this.

item.title: September 11: The heroes of the forgotten maritime rescue mission
item.description: On 11 September 2001 nearly 500,000 people were evacuated by boat from southern Manhattan.

item.title: Council officials' blunder over 'proper whack' planning decisions
item.description: Owner of The Happy Pants Ranch Amey James is told her plan is "Whack. No mate, proper whack".

item.title: JLS comeback: 'The energy is still there'
item.description: The hit boy band tell Radio 1 Newsbeat why they're back after an eight-year break.

item.title: Climate change: Animals shapeshifting to stay cool, study says
item.description: Warm-blooded animals are evolving to have larger beaks, legs and ears to stay cool, scientists say.

item.title: Could the boost to women’s football mean more online abuse?
item.description: Aston Villa player Anita Asante says she worries whether players will be able to ‘manage’ potential online abuse.

item.title: Universal Credit: What £20 means to me
item.description: People on Universal Credit who received a £20 extra per week during the pandemic, explain how the extra money helped and how they will cope without it.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: Canada federal election: Two years of Justin Trudeau in two minutes
item.description: As Canadians prepare to head back to the polls, here are some key moments since the last election.

item.title: CEO Secrets: The bra boss busting stereotypes
item.description: Leanne Cahill, CEO of Bravissimo, shares her journey from shop floor to boardroom in retail.

item.title: Somali feminist: Facebook is being used to silence me
item.description: Hanna Paranta has faced assassination attempts and now online attacks for helping abused women.

item.title: Baby Queen: Meet pop's boldest, sharpest new voice
item.description: "I have a problem releasing music that doesn't feel significant," says Bella Latham, aka Baby Queen.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Paris attacks: Historic day of reckoning for night of terror
item.description: Survivors and families attend the long-awaited trial of 20 men accused of the deadly 2015 attacks.

item.title: US Open: Why it is right to be excited about 'wise' & 'fearless' Emma Raducanu
item.description: As British teenager Emma Raducanu reaches the US Open quarter-finals, BBC Sport looks at why it is right to be excited by her journey.

item.title: Climate change: Shetland's power struggle between oil and wind
item.description: The row over plans for a new oil field at Cambo has placed Shetland in the heart of the debate over energy production.

item.title: Pensions: What is the triple lock and why has it been 'suspended'?
item.description: The government has changed a policy which determines the annual rise in the state pension.

item.title: India jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
item.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

item.title: Nizar Banat: The death shaking the Palestinian leadership
item.description: The killing of Nizar Banat in Palestinian custody has fuelled rare protests calling for change.

item.title: Why social workers are being embedded in schools
item.description: A new project is embedding social workers in schools. How is it improving family life?

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: 'It's surreal but I'm ready' - Raducanu set for US Open quarter-final
item.description: British teenager Emma Raducanu says her stunning run to the US Open quarter-finals is "surreal", putting her success down to feeling "really, really happy".

item.title: 'We can't let our guard down' - Southgate warns against England complacency
item.description: England boss Gareth Southgate wants to maintain their 100% record in World Cup qualifying against Poland on Wednesday.

item.title: 'Mood shifts with World Cup destiny in Scotland's own hands'
item.description: Winning in Austria has not only put Scotland in control of their World Cup hopes, it has altered perceptions too, writes Tom English.

item.title: Eight to miss Premier League games as Brazil invoke ban
item.description: Eight Premier League players will be stopped from playing for their clubs this weekend after Brazilian football authorities trigger a Fifa rule to prevent them appearing.

item.title: Buttler will definitely play in fifth Test against India - Root
item.description: Jos Buttler will return as England's vice-captain and wicketkeeper for the fifth and final Test against India at Emirates Old Trafford.

item.title: Social care: 'It's too late for my mum, her house has been sold'
item.description: Some people who have paid tens of thousands of pounds on social care feel let down by the new plans.

item.title: Will people already paying for care get extra help? Your questions
item.description: We answer your questions about the the government's plans to reform social care in England.

item.title: ‘We had to sell the house right away’
item.description: Sharon and Edith tell the BBC how they have been impacted by the crisis in social care.

item.title: Social care changes at-a-glance
item.description: The government's promising to restrict costs for families - but what is changing and how will it be funded?

item.title: What will the new tax cost me?
item.description: A new health and social care tax is being introduced, Boris Johnson has announced.

item.title: Business bosses warn new tax could hit jobs
item.description: Lobby groups have described a new health and social care tax as "ill-timed" and "illogical".

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: Covid passports: Nightclubs, concerts and festivals... where will I need one?
item.description: Covid passports to prove vaccination will be required from the end of September in crowded indoor venues in England.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Millions of children, including 16- to 17-year-olds, are now being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Taliban needs UN's humanitarian aid - UN boss
item.description: In return, the new regime must provide conditions for the UN to work in Afghanistan, secretary general tells BBC.

item.title: Afghanistan: Dentist fears for family in hiding from Taliban
item.description: Suleyman Sakha says his in-laws, who worked for a humanitarian organisation, are living in dread.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who's who in the Taliban leadership
item.description: What we know about the top figures in the militant group that has taken control of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
